resources.string: Installation error: native library not found.
More keys needed to unlock message.

ArcanaCard allows you to make short hidden messages that require multiple keys to reveal. You 'mint' your message with it's keys, ie. they become a set. Each set is called a 'Topic' and although topics have cryptic names you can put a clue on the message or any of the keys. 

To reveal a message you must have the message card and at least two of the key cards; exactly how many keys you require will depend on the 'locks' setting when the topic was minted. 

ArcanaCard shares topics using QRCodes and so needs you to install a QRCode scanning app, like ZXing or Google Goggles. As well, it works best with physically printed QRCodes that you can trade between friends or hide for friends to find. 

To get started press the NEW BUTTON to create your first topic.

You create a new topic with a message, hidden by a number of locks and unlockable using some number of keys. 

'Keys' are the number of completely interchangeable keys that will be created. It can be larger than the number of locks on a message but not smaller. 

'Locks' are the number of keys that someone must possess to reveal your hidden message. They must have your message card as well! 

'Clues' can be attached to keys and can be read as soon as a key is scanned. Clues are not encrypted. Choose clues that are interesting or helpful, ie. the locations of other keys or perhaps portions of a text. 

Use the AUTOFILL MENU to get started with some quote-based games from some public domain texts.

Autofill will create an example game for you using some works that are in the public domain. 

This kind of game requires you to guess the title of an author's book or play from only seeing famous portions of its text. You lose if you collect enough keys to unlock it. 

Autofill works with your current key and lock settings, so you can customize the difficulty of each game.
Great work, you\'ve made a new topic!

Each card contains information about the set it was minted with. ArcanaCard can show you this information and how many cards of each topic you currently have. The main screen shows these indicators in the top right of each topic: 

* M nK nL nT 

'*' Means you can read the hidden message because you have the message card and enough of the keys to unlock it, 

'M' Means you have scanned the message card (but you may not be able to read it if you don't have enough keys!), 

'nK' Shows that you have collected 'n' keys for a particular topic, 

'nL' Shows how many locks are on the message. To unlock a hidden message you would need the message card and 'n' keys, 

'nT' Shows that there are a total of 'n' keys made for this message.

On the main screen you can short-press on a topic to read a message or long-press to access other topic-related options where you can view the QRCodes or send them to a PC for printing. \n\nExporting your topic to a PC and printing the codes is the way to take ArcanaCard out into the real world.
This version of ArcanaCard is restricted to 7 keys, 7 locks and 63 character messages and clues.

TLDR: This software is a toy. Don't do anything serious with it.
 
By using this software you accept the following:

This software contains components developed by tereslogica <tereslogica@gmail.com> as well as the following licensed components: 

pegwit, Public Domain, License granted by George Barwood <george.barwood@dial.pipex.com>, Paulo S.L.M. Barreto <pbarreto@uninet.com.br> and Mr. Tines <tines@windsong.demon.co.uk> 

sha1, Public Domain, License granted by Steve Reid <steve@edmweb.com> 

zxing, Copyright 2007 ZXing Authors, Apache 2.0 License, http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html 

Portions of works by William Shakespeare, Jules Verne and Beatrix Potter all Public Domain.

This application stores hidden messages using the rc4 cipher with a 56 bit key and uses Shamir\'s Secret Sharing Algorithm with 56 bit coefficients for key reconstruction. Topic tokens are signed with per-topic, single-use 96 bit authentication keys. All field arithmetic is performed on the non-prime binary-field GF(2^112). This application claims export-restriction exempt status under Wassenaar 5.A.2.a.1.a and US EAR 5x992.
